thread.title: Pedro proves he's up for the cup as Chelsea keep double hopes alive by beating Wolves
thread.title_full: Pedro proves he's up for the cup as Chelsea keep double hopes alive by beating Wolves

author: Steve Bates
title: Pedro proves he's up for the cup as Chelsea keep double hopes alive by beating Wolves
text:
Sport Opinion Pedro proves he's up for the cup as Chelsea keep double hopes alive by beating Wolves The Spaniard has scored four goals in three FA Cup matches for Chelsea and is enjoying an impressive individual season Share Pedro broke the deadlock for Chelsea against Wolves (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get Chelsea FC   
Pedro has been one of Chelsea's unsung Premier League heroes all season – and his FA Cup goals are catapulting Chelsea towards yet another Wembley date too. 
Two in the third round at Peterborough, another against fourth-round victims Brentford and last night the live-wire Spaniard grabbed the key goal to set-up victory at Molineux to deflate a pumped-up Wolves side looking for another Premier League scalp. 
More often than not it's Diego Costa and Eden Hazard who hog the headline limelight. 
But as well as a league crown, Pedro's on a mission to drive Chelsea to their eighth FA Cup final in 20 years – and his 65th-minute goal was a killer for Wolves. 
Costa added the icing on a ruthlessly professional display by Antonio Conte's stars, sweeping home a tidy 89th-minute finish for his 16th of the season. Pedro headed Chelsea into the lead after 65 minutes at Molineux (Photo: PA) Diego Costa slid home Chelsea's second in the 89th minute (Photo: Darren Walsh) 
Victory left recalled skipper John Terry delighted at Chelsea's focus: “Seeing results in the last round and before the game it was a wake-up call that we didn't need but it's nice to get it before you go out there. 
“We wanted to be in the hat for the next round so we were as prepared as always and we had to dig in because they started well and made it difficult for us. 
“The team are playing well and it's tough for me to get back in so when you get a chance you have to play well. All we can do is be there for the ones that are playing and pushing them and letting the manager know you are there if needed.” 
Despite defeat, Wolves manager Paul Lambert was far from dejected saying: “I'm not one for being happy at defeat but my players were outstanding. View gallery Wolves manager Paul Lambert was delighted with the performance of his team (Photo: REUTERS) 
“They did everything I asked of them but we needed the goal from George Saville to give us something to hang on to. We went toe to toe with one of the best sides in football and I've got nothing but praise for the team, I'm very proud of them.” 
Jose Mourinho claimed it's dangerous and disrespectful to play weak teams in the FA Cup – and Conte clearly agrees. 
The Chelsea boss made seven changes, but all his big guns Costa, Hazard, Pedro, Willian and Fabregas were on show and the only gamble was flanking Terry with talented youngsters Kurt Zouma and Nathan Ake in a three man back-line ahead of Asmir Begovic. 
Hardly a Klopp-style reserve side - and just as well too with Lambert's confident stars in the mood to add another upset to a day of Cup shocks. Eden Hazard started for Chelsea against Wolves (Photo: PA) Unlike Jurgen Klopp, Antonio Conte, pictured, played a strong team against Wolves (Photo: REUTERS) 
Wolves put the skids under Liverpool in the last round scoring after just 52 seconds at Anfield. 
This time it took the Championship side all of four minutes to create a scoring chance – and it should have been a goal. 
An early ball played into the heart of a re-shuffled three man Chelsea defence fell to unmarked George Saville. 
The former Stamford Bridge trainee lined up his left foot shot but drove the ball against the post with Chelsea's defence in a panic. George Saville almost opened the scoring for Wolves (Photo: Stu Forster) Saville was on Chelsea's books as a youth player (Photo: Darren Walsh) 
Prowling the technical area Lambert felt the miss more than most – rightly realising it could be the defining moment in the game. 
But it set the tone for a confident, gutsy Wolves show against Conte's Premier League leaders who quickly discovered being less than focused wasn't an option. 
Wolves managed to win at Anfield with 21% possession and although they managed more than that against Chelsea, Conte's stars aren't ripping-up the Premier League for nothing. 
Cesc Fabregas carved open the Wolves defence to tee up Willian with a tasty 11th-minute opening but keeper Carl Ikeme blocked his way to goal. Chelsea were simply too good for their Championship opponents (Photo: REUTERS) The Blues will find out their fate in Sunday's last-eight draw (Photo: Darren Walsh) 
Wolves screamed for a penalty after 20 minutes when Andreas Weimann went down in the box under a Willian challenge but referee Jon Moss was unmoved despite Lambert doing a war dance. 
Wolves launched plenty of crosses into Chelsea's box but with Terry expertly marshalling his defence there were few dramas for Begovic. 
Helder Costa was a menace at Liverpool but he dazzled rarely in this tie, much like Hazard who had an off night too. 
The Belgian teed up Fabregas late in the game but he spurned the chance to finish the contest, pulling his shot wide. Costa was more ruthless moments later after Matt Doherty cruelly ran the ball into his path. poll loading Will Chelsea win the Double this season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
